Carpaccio is a dish of raw meat or fish thinly sliced or pounded thin and served 
mainly as an appetizer. It was invented and popularised by Giuseppe Cipriani 
from Harry's Bar in Venice during the second half of the twentieth century. It was 
named after Venetian painter Vittore Carpaccio. ... Venetian painter known for the 
characteristic red and white tones of his work.
